title: Newtons first law - box pulled on varied surface

content.description: A constant, horizontal tension <math alttext="F sub T" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>F</mi><mtext>T</mtext></msub></math> is exerted on a box as it slides to the right across a rough, horizontal surface, as shown in the figure. In the region to the left of Point <math alttext="P" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">P</mi></math>, the magnitude of <math alttext="F sub T" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>F</mi><mtext>T</mtext></msub></math> is equal to the magnitude of the force of kinetic friction between the box and the surface. After the box reaches Point <math alttext="P" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">P</mi></math>, friction between the box and the surface becomes negligible and <math alttext="F sub T" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>F</mi><mtext>T</mtext></msub></math> remains constant. Consider the horizontal velocity of the box when it is on the surface before Point <math alttext="P" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">P</mi></math> and after Point <math alttext="P" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">P</mi></math>. Which statements below correctly describe and justify the motion of the box in the two regions?
